text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

Minor editorial changes have been made throughout this IRM. Also, website addresses, legal references, and IRM references were reviewed and updated as necessary. Other significant changes to this IRM include the following:

Prior IRM Reference New IRM Reference Description of Change N/A N/A The title of IRM 4.10.9 has been changed from “Work- papers” to “Workpaper System and Case File Assembly” in order to more clearly reflect the content. N/A Throughout IRM Deleted references to Form 4700 and replaced with Form 4318-OA. IRM 4.10.9.1 IRM 4.10.9.1 Updated and clarified guidance to include lead sheets and case file organization. N/A IRM 4.10.9.3 Moved RGS content from IRM 4.10.9.4.5 to a separate subsec- tion. N/A IRM 4.10.9.2 Added new subsec- tion to address ex parte communica- tions when documenting case files.

Prior IRM Reference New IRM Reference Description of Change IRM 4.10.9.2 IRM 4.10.9.4 Renamed and revised to provide an overview of the workpaper system. Moved all content related to lead sheets to IRM 4.10.9.6. Moved all content related to workpapers to IRM 4.10.9.7. IRM 4.10.9.3 IRM 4.10.9.5 Moved all content related to the activity record before discus- sion of administrative and issue lead sheets to improve flow and updated guidance. IRM 4.10.9.3.1 IRM 4.10.9.8 Moved, renumbered, and updated guidance. N/A IRM 4.10.9.6 Moved all content related to administra- tive and issue lead sheets to new sub- section. Updated and clarified guidance. IRM 4.10.9.4 IRM 4.10.9.7 Moved all content related to workpapers into one subsection. Updated and clarified guidance. IRM 4.10.9.5 IRM 4.10.9.9 Moved, renumbered and updated guidance. IRM 4.10.9.5.2 (1)h IRM 4.10.9.9.2(1)g Revised procedures to instruct examiners to close case using Tax Module All (TXMODA) instead of IMFOLT/BMFOLT. N/A IRM 4.10.9.10 Added new subsec- tion to address mailing cases.

EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS IRM 4.10.9, dated February 1, 2010, is superseded.

and Case File Assembly

) This section provides guidelines for the development of lead sheet and workpaper content and for workpaper and case file organization. These lines are provided to promote quality and consistency in the preparation and completion of lead sheets, workpapers, and case files. (

) Leads sheets and workpapers are the written records that support the audit findings. Lead sheets and workpapers must document the audit activities including audit steps and techniques applied, tests performed, information obtained, and conclusions reached. They must include all the information necessary to support the audit results. (

) Lead sheets and workpapers serve four basic purposes: a. Provide a framework to plan the audit, including the analysis of internal documents, and set the scope of the exam. b. Document the evidence gathered, audit steps and techniques applied, tests performed, and analyses conducted during the audit process. c. Support the factual and technical conclusions. d. Provide a basis for review by management and other stakeholders Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA) reviewers Counsel). Well prepared workpapers facilitate review by numerous customers. (
) Lead sheets and supporting workpapers constitute official government documents. They must be professional and objective in tone and language well as free of unwarranted personal opinion and bias. (

) Examiners must contemporaneously update the lead sheets and supporting workpapers during the audit. As issues are resolved, lead sheets and pers should be finalized, printed and included in the case file. (
) Case files are not considered to be ex parte communications within the of Rev. Proc.
IRB.

It is permissible to ously include statements or documents that are pertinent to the examiner’s consideration of the case. However, examiners must refrain from placing memoranda, or other documents that normally would not be included in the case file in the ordinary course of developing the case if the reason for including this material is to attempt to influence Appeals’ decision-making process. Note: The case file must not include “gratuitous” comments in the case history, memorandum to the file, or a transmittal document (e.g. Form
), if the substance of the comments would be prohibited if they were to Appeals separate and apart from the case file. (
) See IRM
, Ex Parte Communication Procedures, and the Ex Parte munications page of the M
BSE website, for additional information and guidance. (
) RGS is the software program utilized in the examination process to: (cid:
) Compute corrected tax, interest, penalties, and generate audit reports (cid:
) Create various forms and letters (cid:
) Document the examiner’s actions and findings (cid:
) Process and archive audit results Internal Revenue Manual
Workpaper System and Case File Assembly 4.10.9

) Leads sheets and workpapers are the written records that support the audit findings. Lead sheets and workpapers must document the audit activities including audit steps and techniques applied, tests performed, information obtained, and conclusions reached. They must include all the information necessary to support the audit results. (

) Lead sheets and workpapers serve four basic purposes: a. Provide a framework to plan the audit, including the analysis of internal documents, and set the scope of the exam. b. Document the evidence gathered, audit steps and techniques applied, tests performed, and analyses conducted during the audit process. c. Support the factual and technical conclusions. d. Provide a basis for review by management and other stakeholders Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA) reviewers Counsel). Well prepared workpapers facilitate review by numerous customers. (

) Form
or Form

-OA is the cover sheet that indexes the and issue lead sheets, as well as supporting documents (e.g. information document requests, correspondence, case building materials). It pertains to one taxpayer (or both spouses for jointly filed returns) and includes all tax years under audit. If there are more than three years under audit, examiners must also use Form
-A, Continuation Sheet for Form
, Examination Workpapers Index. (
) The workpaper system is designed to facilitate consistent organization of files and eliminate duplication. (
) Lead sheets and supporting workpapers: (cid:
) Reflect the evidence gathered, explanations, analyses and conclusions reached. (cid:
) Effectively explain the issues addressed during the audit. (cid:
) Provide the evidence to reflect the scope and depth of the audit. (cid:
) Support the determination of the tax liability. (cid:
) Reflect the audit trail, allowing a subsequent reviewer to trace a or event and related information from beginning to end. (

chronicles all actions on the part of the examiner, group manager, clerical support staff, taxpayer and/or the taxpayer’s representative, etc. during the course of the audit. (

is a brief summary of actions taken and in some cases will reference other workpapers for more detail. All entries on Form
should written factually and professionally, omitting personal opinions. (

) Examiners must use the administrative and issue lead sheets in the RGS program. See IRM
, RGS Inventory/Case Management, for addi- tional information. (
) Administrative and issue lead sheets serve as an index and summary for porting workpapers and provide the following benefits: (cid:
) Consistent format, making the case file easier to review (cid:
) Streamline the audit process (cid:
) Include audit steps that assist the examiner through issues with which are unfamiliar (cid:
) Allow audit steps to be added, modified or eliminated (
) See IRM
, Lead Sheets, and IRM
, Documents Included in RGS, for additional information about lead sheets. (

) Administrative lead sheets address the administrative items requiring by the examiner (e.g., initial interview, required filing checks and minimum income probes). They are also used as guides to assist the examiner with properly completing the audit. Caution: If a lead sheet contains check boxes, they should be used to notate applicability of an action taken. Supporting documentation to explain action taken should be included. Generally, check boxes by are not adequate supporting documentation. IRM
), Pre- Contact Planning or Examination Activities, provides additional regarding the use of check boxes. (
) In general, administrative lead sheets do not contain an adjustment grid playing “Per Return” and “Per Exam” amounts. (
) The administrative lead sheets listed below are mandatory for revenue and are generally applicable to all income tax cases: a.
, Revenue Agent Audit Plan, b.
, Group Manager Concurrence Meeting (mandatory for GS-
and below), c.
, Initial Taxpayer Contact, Internal Revenue Manual

, Issues, for additional guidance. (
) Issue lead sheets are used to: a. Document the adjustments, conclusion, audit steps, facts, law, and taxpay- er’s position for examined issues, and b. Index and reference supporting workpapers. (

) In general, issue lead sheets contain an adjustment grid that displays a “Per Return”, “Per Exam”, and “Adjustment” amount. However, there are some issues that do not result in an adjustment to the tax return (e.g. innocent spouse and identity theft), and as a result the related issue lead sheet does not contain an adjustment grid.
Note: All issues must be listed on Form 4318 or Form 4318-OA.

An issue lead sheet is required for all issues. If an issue does not have a specific lead sheet, a generic lead sheet must be used. See IRM Lead Sheets, for additional information. The examiner or group manager should document all managerial discussions
The examiner or group manager should document all managerial discussions on the relevant issue lead sheet or on Form 9984.
System and Case File Assembly 4.10.9
) Issue lead sheets should contain the following: a. Header - See IRM
b. Content - See IRM
c. Footer - See IRM

) Issue lead sheets must reflect the issue name, adjustments (when conclusion, audit steps, facts, law, and taxpayer’s position in the body. This information should be presented in a logical order so reviewers can easily determine what audit steps and actions were taken to support the conclusion. a. Adjustments -- Document the adjustments resulting from the audit. The lead sheet will detail the “Per Return,” “Per Exam,” and “Adjustment” amounts with each adjustment referenced to the supporting workpapers. b. Conclusion -- Document a conclusion summarizing the disposition of each issue. c. Audit Steps -- Document references to the supporting workpapers that contain the procedures and the audit techniques performed during the audit. Note: Issue-specific lead sheets are designed with suggested audit steps that are applicable to the issue. Examiners should customize the audit steps for specific case. Steps that are not applicable should be deleted and steps should be added when warranted. d. Facts -- Document the facts upon which the adjustment is based. The statement should be in narrative form. The facts must be relevant to the issue and should be stated accurately and objectively. Facts favorable to both the Service’s and taxpayer’s position must be included. e. Law -- Document the applicable law relied upon to resolve the issue no change and adjusted issues). The applicable law should be correctly cited and explained (if necessary). Rulings, opinions, and decisions upon should be clearly stated and identified in the explanation. If the ad- justment is supported by multiple code sections of tax law, they all must be reflected. For example, to support a disallowance of business expenses, IRC
(a), ordinary and necessary business expenses, and IRC

, lack of substantiation, should be incorporated into the if both are applicable. f. Taxpayer’s Position -- Document the taxpayer’s position. The position should be stated objectively (in narrative form) if known. The authority, if any, that the taxpayer used as the basis of their argument should also be cited. If the taxpayer provided a written position include and index it with the workpapers. If the taxpayer does not a position, the examiner should document that fact in this section of the lead sheet. (

) Workpapers support the information included on the lead sheets and, when applicable, should reflect: a. What the examiner reviewed, requested and inspected to audit the issue. At a minimum, the workpapers should explain why the issue was how a sample size was determined (when applicable), and what documents were requested and inspected.

Format b. Content - See IRM
c. Footer - See IRM

) Issue lead sheets must reflect the issue name, adjustments (when conclusion, audit steps, facts, law, and taxpayer’s position in the body. This information should be presented in a logical order so reviewers can easily determine what audit steps and actions were taken to support the a. Adjustments -- Document the adjustments resulting from the audit. The lead sheet will detail the “Per Return,” “Per Exam,” and “Adjustment” amounts with each adjustment referenced to the supporting workpapers. b. Conclusion -- Document a conclusion summarizing the disposition of each issue. c. Audit Steps -- Document references to the supporting workpapers that contain the procedures and the audit techniques performed during the audit.
a. Adjustments

Document the adjustments resulting from the audit. The lead sheet will detail the “Per Return,” “Per Exam,” and “Adjustment” amounts with each adjustment referenced to the supporting workpapers. b. Conclusion
Document a conclusion summarizing the disposition of each issue. c. Audit Steps
Document references to the supporting workpapers that contain the procedures and the audit techniques performed during the audit.

Issue-specific lead sheets are designed with suggested audit steps that are applicable to the issue. Examiners should customize the audit steps for their specific case. Steps that are not applicable should be deleted and additional

applicable to the issue. Examiners should customize the audit steps for their specific case. Steps that are not applicable should be deleted and additional steps should be added when warranted. d. Facts -- Document the facts upon which the adjustment is based. The statement should be in narrative form. The facts must be relevant to the issue and should be stated accurately and objectively. Facts favorable to both the Service’s and taxpayer’s position must be included. e. Law -- Document the applicable law relied upon to resolve the issue (both no change and adjusted issues). The applicable law should be correctly cited and explained (if necessary). Rulings, opinions, and decisions relied upon should be clearly stated and identified in the explanation. If the ad- justment is supported by multiple code sections of tax law, they all must be reflected. For example, to support a disallowance of business expenses, IRC
(a), ordinary and necessary business expenses, and IRC

, lack of substantiation, should be incorporated into the narrative, if both are applicable. f. Taxpayer’s Position -- Document the taxpayer’s position. The taxpayer’s position should be stated objectively (in narrative form) if known. The legal authority, if any, that the taxpayer used as the basis of their argument should also be cited. If the taxpayer provided a written position statement, include and index it with the workpapers. If the taxpayer does not provide a position, the examiner should document that fact in this section of the lead sheet.

a. What the examiner reviewed, requested and inspected to audit the issue. At a minimum, the workpapers should explain why the issue was audited, how a sample size was determined (when applicable), and what documents were requested and inspected.

b. Specific expenditures examined, verified and the conclusions reached. At a minimum, the workpaper should identify the amount examined, verified and the documents inspected (invoices, check numbers), as well as date and payee. c. Questions or items raised during the audit and the conclusions reached. d. Photocopies of relevant documents secured from the taxpayer and/or resentative. Care should be given to consider the facts and of a particular case when determining relevance. For example, bank ments would be relevant when they are used to propose an adjustment income. e. Internal source documents (e.g. Information Return Program (IRP) or Computer Files On Line (CFOL)). For example, IMFOLI/BMFOLI to support conclusions related to prior/subsequent/related return filings. f. Issue-specific correspondence from the taxpayer and/or representative. (

) Many customers will use the case file; therefore, the quality and legibility of workpapers are very important. In most instances, workpapers are prepared using computerized software. Workpapers generated using a computer a product with a professional appearance. When it is necessary to prepare handwritten workpapers and supporting details, they must be legible. (
) Examiners should use their computer to prepare workpapers and reports in a way that will most efficiently and effectively document the audit process. (

) The appearance of the workpapers reflects the professionalism and skills of the examiner. Poorly prepared workpapers can adversely impact the credibility. Additional reasons workpapers should be neat, legible, and gram- matically correct are: a. To assist in preparing reports. b. Possible use in a court of law many months or years later. In a litigated case, the workpapers become court exhibits. As a witness in the case, examiner must rely on his or her workpapers to answer questions regarding actions taken and conclusions reached. c. Taxpayer requests for workpapers or the case file. d. Efficient transfer of the case in the event the original examiner is unavail- able. The new examiner must rely on the workpapers to develop issues that have already been identified, and continue the exam without ing actions. e. Potential use in a subsequent audit. f. Potential reviews performed by managers, Technical Services, Appeals, the Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS), Interest Abatement Coordinator, TIGTA, Government Accounting Office (GAO), etc. g. Facilitate closing by Centralized Case Processing (CCP). (

) To ensure workpapers are neat, legible, grammatically correct, and easily un- derstood the examiner should: a. Use vocabulary that is easily understood; b. Avoid using jargon (use common terms in place of legal jargon); c. Provide explanations when acronyms are used the first time; d. Verify that spelling and punctuation are correct (use spell-checker and grammar-checker if available); e. Prepare workpapers contemporaneously to avoid unnecessary rewriting; and Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
S

System and Case File Assembly 4.10.9

Workpapers should be assembled in uniform size. If odd sized paper or documents are included, they should be folded to the appropriate size. machine tapes or other small size documents should be attached to uniform
sized sheets of paper.
Workpapers must include a header and footer with the following information:
Note: If a workpaper is prepared on multiple dates, the examiner should note date that significant work was done. (
) Footer Information - Indexed page number. (
) All workpapers should be numbered. For example, if the issue lead sheet reflects “Bad Debt Expense” as Issue
, then the workpapers associated with the issue should be numbered in chronological order as
, etc. In addition, see IRM
), for guidance regarding naming files within RGS. (

) Workpapers should be prepared using appropriate cross-referencing as follows: a. Examiners should use the “Workpaper Reference” column on the trative or issue lead sheet to point to the supporting workpaper(s). The supporting workpaper(s) contain the documentation to explain the work performed. b. It is not necessary to cross-reference all supporting workpapers to the lead sheet, however, supporting workpapers should be cross-referenced each other when necessary to document the audit trail. (

) Tick marks are used to simplify documentation of conditions found and work performed. Tick marks do not need to be standardized throughout the case but they must be consistent throughout the workpapers for an issue. Tick explanations must be a part of the workpaper or included in a separate tick mark legend workpaper. (
) Workpapers should be indexed contemporaneously throughout the audit. (
) Document
, Examination Workpaper Index Reference Tabs, should be used by revenue agents to help index audit lead sheets and workpapers to Form
Generally, the information on each tab identifies the numeric and the associated lead sheet as depicted on the Form
) Document
, Office Examination Workpaper Index Reference Tabs, should be used by TCOs to help index audit lead sheets and workpapers to
Note: If a workpaper is prepared on multiple dates, the examiner should note each date that significant work was done.
Document 13005, Office Examination Workpaper Index Reference Tabs, should be used by TCOs to help index audit lead sheets and workpapers to
Examination of the Form
-OA. Generally, the information on each tab identifies the numeric index and the associated lead sheet as depicted on the Form OA. (

) A taxpayer and/or representative can request and receive information from examiner. Documents in the case file can be released unless the Disclosure would seriously impair tax administration. Refer to IRM
, Requests File and Workpapers. (

) Sensitive but Unclassified (SBU) information related to the case must be guarded from unauthorized disclosure. If an examiner determines that information contained in a case is SBU, the information should be placed “To be Opened by Addressee Only” envelope inside the case file. (
) When a case file contains SBU information, Form G TDF
, But Unclassified (SBU) Cover Sheet, must be attached to the front of the file. This will alert users there is SBU information in the file requiring (
) If a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request is received on a case that contains SBU information, a Disclosure Officer will determine if any can be redacted. See IRM
, Review and Redacting, for additional formation. (
) Examiners should keep their files clean of unrelated materials. For when examiners print information from services such as
, they should mediately discard all material on unrelated parties unless such information functionally declared necessary (e.g., to detail specific search See IRM
, Privacy Act Requirement to Maintain Accurate, Timely and Complete Records, for additional guidance. (
) Examiners should pre-plan the case as outlined in IRM
, In-depth Contact Analysis. All pre-plan actions taken should be documented and applicable lead sheets completed to the extent possible. Pre-Plan (

) Examiners should document taxpayer and representative contact made to schedule the initial appointment. Contact information in RGS should be updated, if necessary, based on the initial taxpayer contact. (
) A well-documented interview provides an understanding of the taxpayer’s financial history, business operations, and accounting records. (
) Interview questions must be tailored to gain a clear understanding of the Initial taxpayer, as well as the operations of the taxpayer. (

) Examiners should take brief notes during the interview and note those which need additional development. Extensive note taking can be and hinder the flow of the interview. It is important that the examiner eye contact with the taxpayer during the interview. Immediately following interview, the examiner should use their notes to prepare a memorandum summary of the interview. The memorandum or summary of the interview should not duplicate the interview notes. (
) Audit Technique Guides (ATG) contain suggested interview questions for specific industries and issues. This information may be helpful in planning Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
S
the Form 4318-OA. Generally, the information on each tab identifies the numeric index and the associated lead sheet as depicted on the Form
A well-documented interview provides an understanding of the taxpayer’s financial history, business operations, and accounting records.
) Interview questions must be tailored to gain a clear understanding of the taxpayer, as well as the operations of the taxpayer. (

) Examiners should take brief notes during the interview and note those areas which need additional development. Extensive note taking can be distracting and hinder the flow of the interview. It is important that the examiner maintain eye contact with the taxpayer during the interview. Immediately following the interview, the examiner should use their notes to prepare a memorandum or summary of the interview. The memorandum or summary of the interview should not duplicate the interview notes. (
) Audit Technique Guides (ATG) contain suggested interview questions for
Audit Technique Guides (ATG) contain suggested interview questions for specific industries and issues. This information may be helpful in planning the

and Case File Assembly
page interview. ATGs are available at http://www.irs.gov/Businesses/ Small-Businesses-&-Self-Employed/Audit-Techniques-Guides-ATGs . (
) IRM
, Documenting Interviews, discusses the elements of an ad- equately documented interview and should be referenced when preparing for the interview. (

) Examiners should document their observations when a tour of business or other appropriate site inspection is conducted. The tour should be in sufficient detail to explain what was observed and any conclusions See IRM
, Tours of Business Sites, and IRM
, Case File Documentation. (

) All information critical to the case or that supports an adjustment must be included in the paper case file, including lead sheets, supporting workpapers and any other pertinent documents. Whenever possible, examiners are aged to include all information critical to the case or that supports an adjustment in the RGS electronic case file as well. Examiners need to use good judgment when including information in the RGS electronic case file determining whether the documents add merit or value to the case. See IRM
, Documents Included in RGS, for additional information. (
) When available, the taxpayer’s electronic accounting software backup data (e.g., Quic

ooks®, Sage®, Peachtree®) is used to create a spreadsheet contains numerous financial statement reports (e.g., trial balance, general ledger, journal, etc.) that are used to conduct the audit. During the audit the examiner should determine what electronic records should be included in the case file. In many circumstances, the spreadsheet, indexed to the lead and workpapers, may be sufficient to support the audit adjustments. See
for additional information. (

) Cases created using RGS require regular backup to the file server. dence Examination Automation Support (CEAS) users must back up their inventory weekly to ensure the most recent data is available on the file Examiners are strongly encouraged to complete a backup to the file server every time RGS is accessed. An inventory backup is important to safeguard the contents of each case. When a case is backed up, all files (Word®, Excel®, Adobe®, etc.) stored within the case in RGS are included in the backup. (

) Examiners can use various tools to assist in the preparation of workpapers. These may include word processing, database and spreadsheet applications. Examiners should use the tool that will provide the most utility and in the most efficient and effective manner for the issue being addressed. The M
B/SE website is continuously updated with new releases of tax tion tools that may be helpful. This information may be found on the Issues and Procedures web page. (

) Optional workbooks are available to assist examiners in performing various complex computations including but not limited to depreciation, net operating loss, passive activity limitations, and charitable contribution limitations. These workbooks are available on the Special Applications web page of the RGS website.

) Consideration of penalties must be documented in all audits, including those involving tax shelters and erroneous claims for refund or credit. The applicabil- ity of penalties should be considered during the audit and, if warranted, developed as the audit progresses. Only after all facts and circumstances sur- rounding an audit have been developed can a determination be made as to the application of appropriate penalties. See IRM
, Return Related Penalties.
parer’s responsibility for errors and the assertion or non assertion of the return preparer penalty in the income tax case file. See IRM
for additional guidance. IRC

(a) requires that the Service provide the taxpayer with the name of the penalty, the Internal Revenue Code section under which the penalty is imposed, and a computation of the penalty on the notice (report) imposing penalty. The assertion or non-assertion of penalties must be documented on Lead Sheet

whenever an audit results in a deficiency. The extent of the mentation will depend on the nature of the adjustments and the amounts involved. Canned statements (e.g. “negligence penalty applicable” or “negli- gence penalty deemed to be not applicable”), are not sufficient. The examiner must cite the appropriate regulations, rulings and court that are specific to the case’s facts and circumstances for assertion or non- assertion of penalties. Alternative penalty positions must be documented in the workpapers when plicable (e.g. fraud versus negligence penalties, and various components of the accuracy-related penalty). See IRM
, Alternative Positions, for additional guidance. The examiner must include documentation supporting assertion or non- assertion of a penalty on Lead Sheet
whenever the understatement of tax exceeds the dollar criteria for applying the penalty. Written managerial approval is also required. See IRM
The assertion or non-assertion of the substantial understatement penalty under IRC
(d) must be addressed when the understatement exceeds the greater of
% of the tax required to be shown on the return, or $
for corporations other than S corporations or personal holding companies).
) IRC

(b) provides that prior to assessment, all cases recommending the assertion of certain penalties must have written managerial approval. The group manager must perform a meaningful review of the penalty determination. (
) Managerial review and approval is also required on the non-assertion of penalties when there is a substantial understatement of tax under IRC
(d). The group manager must personally approve non-assertion of the penalty, and should document his or her involvement on Lead Sheet
and Case File Assembly

) Penalties requiring managerial approval must be approved before the case closes from the group. See IRM
), Managerial Approval for Penalty Assessments, and IRM

) During every audit, examiners must be alert to fraud indicators and assert civil fraud penalty when there is clear and convincing evidence to prove that some part of the adjustment to taxable income and/or credits resulting in an Civil underpayment of tax was due to civil fraud. Such evidence must show the payer’s intent to evade tax, which the taxpayer believed to be due. (
) For every case resulting in a deficiency, examiners must document their sideration of fraud, including applicable fraud indicators, even if the civil penalty is not pursued or developed. See IRM
, Indicators of Fraud. document consideration of fraud when the civil fraud penalty is not pursued developed, the examiner should check “No” in the “Assert Penalty” column IRC
and document the fraud indicators and facts supporting non- assertion of the civil fraud penalty in the “Conclusion” section on Lead Sheet
) If the civil fraud penalty is pursued and developed, the examiner must use Lead Sheet
, Fraud Development, to document the facts, law, and er’s position. If the penalty is asserted, Lead Sheet
should also reflect penalty amount and conclusion. Fraud indicators should be documented on Lead Sheet

or a supporting workpaper. In cases where the civil fraud penalty was pursued and developed, but not asserted, the examiner must explain the reasons why it was not asserted in the “Conclusion” section on Lead Sheet
or Lead Sheet
, and cross-reference the other lead sheet. (
) During every audit where the tax return was prepared by a tax return examiners must determine if return preparer penalties are warranted. See
, Tax Return Preparer Defined. This determination is based on the facts and circumstances of the case, including oral testimony and written evidence developed during the audit. (

) Examiners must exercise caution when documenting consideration of return preparer penalties in the related income tax case because the income tax is separate and distinct from the return preparer penalty case. Examiners not propose or discuss return preparer penalties in the presence of the taxpayer. (

) When the return was prepared by a tax return preparer and the audit results a deficiency, examiners must document consideration of return preparer penalties in the income tax case. Examiners must document the “Consider- ation of Preparer/Promoter/Material Advisor Penalties” section of Lead Sheet
, and reference the workpapers containing the facts. (

) The income tax case should reflect the return preparer’s involvement in and responsibility for the preparation of the tax return. ) Proper assembly of a case file helps to minimize delays, administrative problems and procedural errors. Assembly for (

) Each case should be placed in a separate folder. A case constitutes all examined returns and workpapers with the same type of tax for the same taxpayer. Within the folder, the oldest year should be placed on top, by the other years in order, with the most current year on the bottom. (
) All related case folders should be kept together with the key case folder on top. Form
is required for the key and each related case. The must record the related or key case in the “Related Taxpayers or Key section of Form
